title: A Randomised, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Parallel Design, Multicentre Study in Patients With Mild to Moderate Alzheimer's Disease to Investigate the Effect on Cognitive Function as Measured by Repeated CogState Testing in Relation to Effects on Traditional Cognitive Measures After 12 Weeks
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to determine if there is improvement or measurable change in cognition after only one month of treatment with donepezil when using a computerized test battery. The results at one month will be compared with the results at 3 months to evaluate this.
explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is donepezil, a centrally acting acetylcholinesterase (cholinesterase) inhibitor used to improve cognitive function in patients with mild–moderate Alzheimer’s disease; it works by increasing acetylcholine availability and is prescribed for symptomatic cognitive benefit rather than as a biologic disease-modifying agent. citeturn0search6turn0search1turn0search9

Act: Key trial details extracted from the description — randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, mild–moderate AD, assessing short-term (1 month) and 3-month changes on a computerized cognitive battery (CogState) and comparing to traditional cognitive measures after 12 weeks. The drug donepezil is an FDA‑approved small-molecule acetylcholinesterase inhibitor for symptomatic treatment of Alzheimer’s dementia. citeturn1search0turn0search6

Reflect: Classification rationale — this trial evaluates short-term change in cognition after administration of donepezil (a symptomatic cholinesterase inhibitor). According to clinical reviews and systematic reviews, donepezil provides modest cognitive/functional symptomatic benefit but is not considered a disease‑modifying biologic; therefore the trial fits the 'cognitive enhancer' category rather than 'disease‑targeted biologic' or 'disease‑targeted small molecule (disease-modifying)'. citeturn0search8turn0search3

Web search results used (sources): Donepezil drug information and mechanism — MedlinePlus (Donepezil). citeturn0search6; Evidence/review of donepezil efficacy as symptomatic treatment — PubMed evidence-based review (donepezil in AD). citeturn0search1; Systematic review (Cochrane) on donepezil for dementia due to Alzheimer’s disease. citeturn0search8; FDA approval / prescribing information (Aricept donepezil NDA and labeling). citeturn1search0; Additional pharmacology summaries (PubMed/NCBI review). citeturn0search5
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is donepezil, a centrally acting acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitor that increases acetylcholine availability to improve cognition — a symptomatic enhancement of cholinergic neurotransmission rather than a disease‑modifying mechanism. citeturn0search1turn0search6

Act: Key trial details from the description — randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled study in mild–moderate AD assessing cognitive change after donepezil (a cholinesterase inhibitor). Donepezil’s mechanism and its symptomatic cognitive benefit are supported by evidence summaries and systematic reviews. citeturn0search3turn0search0

Reflect: Classification rationale — because donepezil acts by augmenting cholinergic neurotransmission (a neurotransmitter system), the most specific CADRO match is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors (covers interventions that modulate neurotransmitter systems/synaptic signaling). The trial is symptomatic (cognitive enhancer) rather than targeting amyloid, tau, inflammation, or other disease‑modifying pathways, so D is appropriate. citeturn0search1turn0search0
